Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computationally Efficient Solvers for Power System Simulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research: Computationally Efficient Solvers for Power System Simulation

Mariesa Crow, Electrical Engineering, Missouri University of Science & Technology
Maggie Cheng, Computer Science, Missouri University of Science & Technology
Shuwang Li, Applied Mathematics, Illinois Institute of Technology

Abstract:
Several recent advances in computational methods in a variety of fields have brought the goal of real-time dynamic simulation within reach. Unfortunately, many power system analysis tools do not use algorithms that implement state-of-the-art solution techniques due to the time lag of results percolating from one field to another. Therefore, there is a need to bring together the best of the mathematicians, computer scientists, and power engineers to solve realistic problems. In this project, computationally efficient solution methods will be synergistically developed and applied to the problem of achieving real-time power system simulation. Specifically, recent advances in computational science and theoretical computer science will be extended to the problem of electric power networks.
Intellectual Merit: Real-time simulation has long been considered to be a grand challenge in electric power engineering. A realistically sized electric power network problem can generate hundreds of dynamic state variables and 50,000+ algebraic states. The computational complexity of some power system simulations has kept time domain simulation from being used in on-line decision making. If simulations could run in real-time, then power system operators would have situational awareness and could implement on-line control to avoid cascading failures. This tool will assist the operator with proactive measures to limit the extent of the incident, and can significantly improve power system reliability. This project will exploit the expertise and advances in areas of linear solvers from a variety of physical fields and will adapt them for use in power system simulation.

Broader Impact: This project will provide an opportunity for educating a diverse STEM workforce in electric power systems, computer algorithms and applied mathematics. The PIs, the graduate students, and the post-doctoral fellow will enter into a close mentoring relationship that will include one-on-one instruction not only in computational methods, but also ethical research practices, communication skills, and international awareness. The results of this research will be incorporated into multiple graduate classes: Computational Methods for Power Systems andApproximation Algorithms. The PIs will also develop undergraduate course material and pre-college hands-on projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Real-time transient stability simulation has long been considered to be a grand challenge in electric power engineering. In the majority of power system computational problems, the system of equations to be solved depends on a (possibly time-varying) matrix solution. The classical direct approach may be computationally expensive for real-time simulations. Several recent advances in iterative computational methods in a variety of fields help to achieve the goal of real-time dynamic simulation.

The focus of our group is to perform fundamental studies of numerical methods for solving a system of linear equations efficiently using iterative methods and to implement the developed methods to broad range of problems in science and engineering. Besides the tree-code fast algorithm to reduce the arithmetic operation count of matrix-vector multiplication from order of N^2 to O(NlogN), where N is the dimension of the matrix,  we also developed a new way of parallelizing the treecode, showing that the speed-up factor is nearly perfect up to a moderate number of processors. This approach of parallelization can be readily used for other treecodes, 2D or 3D, and for uniform or non-uniform point distribution. Thus far, we have contributed to the development of iterative solvers. Indeed, we also demonstrate the effectiveness of the treecode by computing long-time evolution of microstructure in elastic media, which would be extremely difficult with a direct summation method due to CPU time constraint. The treecode speeds up computations  while fulfilling the stringent precision requirement dictated by the spectrally accurate boundary integral formulations.

There are two primary aspects where this project contributes to science and engineering beyond the problem examined. First, our study has furthered the development of integral methods by incorporating a novel rescaling scheme, which enables one to explore the long-time limiting behavior of moving interface problems in other physical and biological systems, especially when the size of the interface becomes very large compared to its initial size. Thus these numerical results provide insights on the long-time behavior of general non-equilibrium systems.  Second, the new mathematical and adaptive numerical techniques we developed will also have applications beyond the present context. For example, the tree-codes we developed here will be useful in studies of other fields such as bioengineering and materials science, e.g. vesicle dynamics and microstructure growth.

Results have been published in peer-reviewed journals. This project provided an opportunity for educating a diverse STEM workforce in applied mathematics. This research program has enabled the training of four graduate students in computational mathematics and its applications in interdisciplinary physical/biological sciences.
